title: Associate NNS routes with VRFs for drawer details
description:
Enhancement: gather VRF route data from NodeNetworkState (NNS) and associate routes with each VRF node model so routes can be displayed in the VRF drawer Details tab.

Goal:
- For a selected VRF in the visualization, list relevant routes in the drawer Details tab.

Requirements:
- Identify where route entries live in NNS payload and determine route fields needed for display (destination/prefix, next-hop, table ID, protocol, etc. as available).
- Map routes to the correct VRF object using stable association rules (for example table ID and/or VRF interface metadata).
- Expose associated routes on the VRF node view model in a maintainable way.
- Render route list in VRF details UI with sensible empty state when no routes are found.

Notes:
- Keep derivation logic in shared model/selector helpers rather than embedding complex parsing directly in JSX.
- Prefer behavior that is deterministic and testable with fixture-style data.

title: Phantom edge appears left of br-ex slave interface (ens192) unless selected
description:

Repro:
1. Open Node Visualization for a node where ens192 is bound to br-ex.
2. Observe extra/phantom edge on the left side of ens192.
3. Click ens192 => phantom edge disappears.
4. Click any other node => phantom edge reappears.

Expected:
- No phantom/left-floating edge should ever render.
- Edge rendering should be stable regardless of active selected node/highlight state.

Suspected area:
- Connector rendering around topologyEdges and interface-* fallback IDs in NodeVisualization SVG edge rendering logic.

title: Fix incorrect YAML tab link for cluster-scoped resources
description:
When viewing a CUDN (ClusterUserDefinedNetwork) graph node in the drawer, the Links tab has properly functioning links, but the YAML tab's "View Resource in Console" link is incorrect.

**Current Behavior:**
- Links tab: Uses `getResourceLinks()` which correctly checks for namespace and uses `/k8s/cluster` for cluster-scoped resources
- YAML tab: Hardcodes `/k8s/ns/${namespace || 'default'}` which incorrectly adds a namespace component for cluster-scoped resources like CUDN

**Expected Behavior:**
- YAML tab should use the same logic as Links tab: check if namespace exists
  - If namespace exists: `/k8s/ns/${namespace}`
  - If no namespace (cluster-scoped): `/k8s/cluster`

**Technical Details:**
- Issue location: `src/components/NodeVisualization.tsx` line 1198
- Current code: `/k8s/ns/${activeNode.raw.metadata?.namespace || 'default'}/`
- Should use same pattern as `getResourceLinks()` function (line 71-79) which correctly handles cluster-scoped resources
- CUDN is a cluster-scoped resource and should not have `/ns/namespace/` in the URL path

comments.author: dale
comments.text:
✅ FIXED: Updated YAML tab link to use same logic as Links tab:
- Uses resourceRef if available (most consistent approach)
- Falls back to checking namespace: if namespace exists uses /k8s/ns/{namespace}, otherwise uses /k8s/cluster for cluster-scoped resources
- Fixes incorrect /k8s/ns/default path for CUDN (cluster-scoped resource)

title: Draw edges from NAD nodes to upstream bridge or bridge-mapping
description:
Draw an edge between each NAD node and its upstream interface or bridge-mapping in the graph.

**Bridge-based NADs**
- When the NAD spec.config (parsed JSON) has `type=bridge` or `type=cnv-bridge`, it may have a `bridge` field.
- The value of `bridge` is the name of the upstream linux-bridge (or OVS bridge) on the node.
- Draw an edge from the NAD node to the graph node that represents that bridge (same name as the interface node for that bridge).

**Bridge-mapping–based NADs**
- The NAD config may instead have a `physicalNetworkName` field (e.g. for localnet / CUDN-backed networks).
- The value of `physicalNetworkName` is the name of an OVN bridge-mapping (the `localnet` in bridge-mappings).
- Draw an edge from the NAD node to the bridge-mapping node with that localnet (node id `ovn-${localnet}` in the existing code).

**Implementation notes**
- Reuse `parseNadConfig(nad.spec?.config)` to read `type`, `bridge`, and `physicalNetworkName` from the NAD config.
- Bridge interface nodes are identified by interface name (e.g. `bridgeInterfaces` / `resolveNodeId`); bridge-mapping nodes use `ovn-${mapping.localnet}`.
- Add these edges in the same place where other NAD edges are built (e.g. NAD ↔ CUDN), and ensure they are rendered in the connector/edge phase (e.g. `renderConnector` or the `edges` set used for SVG lines).

comments.author: Dale Bewley
comments.text:
Follow-up completed:

• Do not link NAD to bridge-mapping when the NAD is CUDN-backed (getNadUpstreamNodeIdsForEdges filters out ovn-* in that case).
• parseNadConfig now accepts spec.config as either a string or an already-parsed object from the API.
• Regex fallback in getNadUpstreamNodeIds extracts bridge/type/physicalNetworkName from the raw config string when JSON parse fails.
• Connector rendering uses interface-${bridgeName} as fallback when the bridge is rendered as an ovs-interface with that id.

title: Submit operator to Community Operators catalog
description:
Submit the OVN Recon Operator to the Community Operators catalog so it appears in the embedded OperatorHub on OpenShift.

## Research required

- **Contribution process**: Follow the official flow for [community-operators-prod](https://github.com/redhat-openshift-ecosystem/community-operators-prod). Operators for OpenShift 4 embedded OperatorHub go in the `community-operators` directory (not `upstream-community-operators`).
- **Packaging**: Align with [contribution/packaging guidelines](https://k8s-operatorhub.github.io/community-operators/packaging-operator/) (bundle format, CSV, etc.). We already have OLM bundle generation (see `docs/OLM-BUNDLE-GUIDE.md` and `operator/config/manifests/`); may need adjustments for catalog layout (e.g. `operators/<name>/<version>/`).
- **Validation**: Use the [operator test suite](https://k8s-operatorhub.github.io/community-operators/operator-test-suite/) and `operator-sdk bundle validate` before submitting.
- **Legal**: PRs must be signed with the Developer Certificate of Origin (DCO).

## Multi-version OpenShift targeting

Submitting to the catalog introduces a need to target multiple OpenShift versions with our releases:

- **Compatibility**: OpenShift uses the `olm.maxOpenShiftVersion` annotation (and related metadata) so clusters can reason about operator compatibility. Operators that omit it do not block cluster upgrades; setting it incorrectly can block upgrades.
- **Strategy**: Decide how we support multiple OCP Y-streams (e.g. 4.14, 4.15, 4.16+): single bundle with a broad compatibility claim, or version-specific bundles/channels. Document the chosen approach and any CI/release changes (e.g. building or validating against multiple OCP versions).
- **Release workflow**: Our release process (e.g. `operator-release.yaml`, tagging, bundle build) may need to be extended to produce or label bundles in a way that fits the community-operators layout and versioning expectations.

## Open questions

- Exact directory structure and naming expected in community-operators-prod for our operator.
- Whether we need separate PRs or entries for different OCP versions.
- CI requirements (e.g. Red Hat CI) and how to run them before/after opening the PR.

## Success criteria

- Operator is accepted and merged into the `community-operators` directory of community-operators-prod.
- Documentation or runbook updated with the submission steps and any multi-version/release workflow changes.
- Release process clearly supports the chosen strategy for multiple OpenShift versions.

title: Improve OVS Interface Handling and Display
description:
Improve the handling and display of ovs-interfaces to reduce redundancy and improve clarity.

Current Problem:
- Both 'br-ex' ovs-bridge and 'br-ex' ovs-interface are appearing in the Bridges column
- This creates visual redundancy and clutter
- Users may not need to see the ovs-interface separately if its information can be consolidated

Proposed Solution (to be determined):
- Investigate gathering details and metadata from ovs-interfaces
- Display this information on the corresponding ovs-bridge node instead
- Omit the ovs-interface from display (or move it to a different location)
- This would consolidate related information and reduce visual clutter

Implementation considerations:
- Need to identify the relationship between ovs-bridge and ovs-interface (likely by name matching)
- Extract relevant metadata/details from ovs-interface
- Display this information in the bridge node's details/popover
- Filter out ovs-interfaces from the Bridges column (or handle them differently)
- Ensure no information is lost in the consolidation

Open questions:
- What metadata/details from ovs-interface should be displayed on the bridge?
- Should ovs-interfaces be completely hidden or moved to a different column?
- How to handle cases where an ovs-interface exists without a corresponding bridge?
- Should this apply to all ovs-interfaces or only those matching bridge names?

title: Rethink Gravity Algorithm for Edge Crossing Minimization
description:
Redesign the gravity calculation algorithm to minimize edge crossings in the graph visualization.

Current Problem:
- Current gravity is based on connection count, which doesn't consider visual layout
- Nodes in connected paths (e.g., ens192 -> br-ex -> physnet -> machinenet CUDN -> machinenet NAD) should be aligned vertically at the top of their respective columns
- This will prevent edges from crossing other edges

Proposed Solution:
1. Identify connected paths/chains through the graph (especially primary/long paths)
2. Assign lower gravity (higher priority) to nodes that are part of longer connected paths
3. Use a path-aware algorithm that considers:
   - Path length (longer paths get priority)
   - Position in path (earlier nodes in path get priority)
   - Or use a topological sort that considers graph structure

Implementation approach:
- Build a graph representation of all connections
- Identify primary paths (longest paths, or paths with most connections)
- Calculate path-based gravity: nodes in longer paths get lower gravity
- Fallback to connection-count gravity for nodes not in identified paths
- Ensure nodes in the same path align vertically (same Y position across columns)

title: Discover UserDefinedNetworks and add to Networks column with namespace, role, and NAD linkage
description:
Add UserDefinedNetwork (UDN) support to the topology visualization. UDNs are namespace-scoped and behave similarly to CUDNs but with additional display and linkage requirements.

**Discovery**
- Watch UserDefinedNetwork resources (namespace-scoped). Use useK8sWatchResource in NodeNetworkStateDetails (or equivalent) to list UDNs. Decide scope: all namespaces (isList with no namespace) or filter; document the choice.
- Add UserDefinedNetwork type to `src/types.ts` (extends K8sResourceCommon, include spec with role if present, and any fields needed for display/linking).
- Pass UDNs into NodeVisualization (e.g. `udns` prop) alongside `cudns`.

**Networks column**
- Add UDNs to the Networks column so they appear alongside CUDNs. Reuse or extend the existing Networks column rendering to support both CUDN and UDN node kinds.
- **Visual distinction**: CUDN and UDN nodes must be visually different by using a different color (e.g. keep existing color for CUDN nodes and choose a distinct color for UDN nodes so users can tell them apart at a glance).
- Graph node for a UDN must include:
  - **Namespace**: Because UDN is namespace-scoped, the node id should include namespace (e.g. `udn-${namespace}-${name}`) and the node label/title or subtitle should show the namespace (e.g. in the drawer and/or on the node).
  - **Role**: UDN has a role value of either Primary or Secondary. Display this on the graph node (e.g. badge, subtitle, or label so it is visible in the column and in the drawer).

**Attachments and NADs**
- In the same namespace as a UDN, the controller creates a NAD. That NAD should be linked to the UDN and shown in:
  - **Attachments column**: Represent the UDN's "attachment" (the controller-created NAD in the same namespace) in the Attachments column, similar to how CUDN attachments are derived from CUDN status. Link the attachment node to the UDN node.
  - **NADs column**: Ensure the controller-created NAD appears in the NADs column and that an edge (or clear relationship) is drawn from the UDN to this NAD (and optionally from the attachment to the NAD if it helps clarity).

**Implementation notes**
- Reuse patterns from CUDN: node kind registry, resolveNodeId for `udn-${namespace}-${name}`, gravity/sorting, connector rendering (UDN -> attachment, UDN -> NAD).
- Ensure drawer/details view for a UDN node shows namespace, role, and links to the related NAD and any other relevant resources.
- Consider whether "Attachments" for UDN are synthesized (one per UDN, pointing to the NAD in same namespace) or driven by status; document and implement consistently.
